awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Building Chemical Synthesis Networks for Life Cycle Hazard Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
1454414 (Eckelman). Industrial chemicals are fundamental to nearly every aspect of modern society and technology but also present potential hazards to the environment and public health. Robust data on both direct and indirect impacts from chemical production and transport are essential for reliable sustainability assessment of products and policies. Current practices suffer from generic empirical data, lack of statistically validated estimation tools, and poor integration with standard industry and government practices in tracking chemical hazards. This research will enable the next generation of chemicals life cycle assessment (LCA) while providing educational experiences to inspire the next generation of interdisciplinary chemical and environmental scientists. Through carefully structured project tasks, this effort will (1) Create a chemical synthesis network for environmental analysis and data generation, (2) Integrate green chemistry principles into a new computational structure for LCA, and (3) Apply LCA's network structure to inform national assessments of chemical supply chain resilience and vulnerability of critical water and wastewater infrastructure. The associated integrated education and outreach program will provide cutting-edge research opportunities, new courses, online educational materials, and demonstrations. Video modules will connect participants to the physical logistics of our chemical infrastructure, providing a bridge between traditional chemistry instruction and chemical and environmental engineering. Project research will be integrated into the PI's teaching, while new courses will include group projects relevant to research objectives.

The proposed research will create a science-based, spatial, and dynamic modeling platform to enable next-generation sustainability assessment of chemicals. High-quality inventory data for hundreds of chemicals and validated estimation tools for thousands more will constitute an open toolkit for the global modeling community. Mechanistic process models will offer unprecedented accuracy in modeling chemical unit processes for LCA while still maintaining a conserved, network structure of energy and material flows upstream to resource extraction. New algorithms and metrics will integrate the inherent hazard approach of green chemistry with the systems approach of LCA. Research activities will leverage existing computational and modeling facilities at Northeastern and Sandia National Laboratory. The research tasks are anticipated to advance modeling and assessment capabilities in evaluating chemical technologies for public and private decision-making. Data, models, and results will be disseminated widely and structured to enable interoperability with existing modeling platforms. The integrated research and education plan will directly engage local students, teachers, and the public, potentially affecting thousands of students and citizens. The project will broaden participation in science and engineering by recruiting and mentoring student researchers from under-represented groups for high school (Young Scholars, Step-Up Programs), college (REU), and science teachers (RET). Design, delivery, and assessment of education and outreach activities will leverage existing capabilities and expertise from Northeastern's highly successful Center for STEM Education, the Graduate School of Engineering, and the Center for Teaching and Learning through Research and will build on the PI's experience in K-12 science instruction, teacher training, and online education.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to improve the accuracy of sustainability assessments for industrial chemicals.  Robust data on the energy use, material inputs, and emissions from chemical production are essential for reliable sustainability assessment of nearly product on the market. Unfortunately, of the tens of thousands of chemicals currently in commerce, measured data exist for only a few hundred, leaving a large gap in our understanding of environmental performance in the chemicals sector.  Accurate modeling tools are needed to fill this gap, but current practices suffer from overuse of generic datasets, lack of statistically validated estimation tools, and poor integration with standard industry and government practices in tracking chemical hazards. This project created new datasets and modeling tools that are being used around the world to analyze the environmental impacts of chemicals, using the framework of life cycle assessment (LCA), while providing educational experiences to inspire the next generation of interdisciplinary chemical and environmental scientists.

 

The project started with a comprehensive comparison of modeling approaches for filling chemicals production data gaps, with recommendations and technical guidance on which methods to use in which situations.  Using sophisticated chemical engineering simulations, hundreds of additional datasets were created, particularly for fine and specialty chemicals and pharmaceuticals.  This work expanded the known LCA datasets for pharmaceuticals by a factor of 3.  Another collection of 150 datasets represent the largest collection of internally-consistent data for chemicals production ever assembled.  This collection was then harnessed to build a model that can predict the environmental performance of any chemical production process.  In addition to examining environmental performance of production (so called gate-to-gate assessments), novel metrics and algorithms were developed and applied to quantify chemical hazards throughout a chemical supply chain. In many cases, the most dangerous aspect of a chemical was found to be the toxicity or physical hazards of its precursors and the resulting risks to workers.  The project research was published through 20 peer-reviewed publications in leading journals and cited by several thousand other scientists and researchers. 

 

The tools and data sets developed during the project were applied in substantial collaborations with researchers and professionals outside of the principal discipline of the project, specifically the health care and cultural heritage sectors.  In health care, project research on chemicals and pharmaceuticals has been used to conduct detailed sustainability assessments of health care supply chains.  The PI has been involved in numerous health care carbon assessment initiatives, including with the NHS in England and the US National Academy of Medicine and with major pharmaceutical and diagnostics companies. Testimony citing this work was given by colleagues at a hearing called by the U.S. House Ways and Means Committee in 2022, to which the PI was invited. In cultural heritage, methods for new chemicals assessment developed under this project has been used by the PI in a long-term collaboration with conservation professionals who want to understand the environmental and health implications of their discipline?s use of chemicals.  This has led to the creation of a website, hosted by the American Institute of Conservation, with a collection of case studies, factsheets, and custom-built calculators that allows cultural heritage professionals to apply methods of chemicals LCA in their own projects and practices.  The website has received more than 35,000 hits since its inception, which is impressive given the relatively small size of the profession. Data on chemical supply chains for art conservation was incorporated into an exhibition at the American Institute for Conservation meeting in Los Angeles, CA, with thousands in attendance.  Through conferences, webinars, and workshops, the PI has trained hundreds of health care and museum professionals in the use of LCA to evaluate chemical risks and life cycle environmental impacts and given seminars at over a dozen educational institutions in the US, UK, and Spain.

 

The project supported the full training of a doctoral student in chemical engineering and partial support for three additional doctoral students in civil & environmental engineering, all of whom were from under-represented groups.  The project also provided research opportunities for 10+ high-school and undergraduate students, as well as professional development opportunities for other educators.  Four domestic high school students who worked on the project during Summer 2016 and Summer 2017 declared chemistry/engineering as their undergraduate majors, while a high-school science teacher and a chemistry professor at a neighboring public higher education institutions used the project materials to create educational games and class exercises.  Project research and materials on chemicals infrastructure modeling were incorporated into undergraduate courses at Northeastern University, including CIVE1200 'Experiencing Urban Infrastructure', CIVE5275 'Life Cycle Assessment of Materials, Products, and Infrastructure', and CIVE 5699 'Design and Development of Modern Infrastructure', reaching approximately 250 students over the duration of the project.  Project results were also used to create photographic visualizations shown in public exhibits and a website (www.lcaart.com).
